title: Pyogenic Liver Abscess
diagnosis_topic: Infection of hepatic parenchyma resulting in abscess formation
setup_script: A 55-year-old man with a history of diabetes presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, and right upper quadrant abdominal pain for one week. He denies jaundice. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.reply: Vital signs are BP 120/75 mmHg, HR 102 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 38.7 °C.
Exam shows tender hepatomegaly in the right upper quadrant. No Murphy’s sign is elicited.
Labs reveal WBC 20,000/µL, alkaline phosphatase elevated, mild transaminase elevation. Blood cultures are pending.
Right upper quadrant ultrasound demonstrates a 5 cm hypoechoic lesion in the right lobe of the liver.
CT abdomen confirms a multiloculated abscess in the right lobe of the liver.
Broad-spectrum antibiotics are started covering enteric Gram-negative organisms and anaerobes (ceftriaxone plus metronidazole).

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults interventional radiology for drainage
dynamic_flow.reply: A percutaneous catheter is placed, and pus cultures are sent.
The patient develops worsening abdominal pain, fever spikes to 40 °C, and he becomes hypotensive at BP 85/50 mmHg.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates resuscitation at this point
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient improves hemodynamically after IV fluids and antibiotics, but remains tachycardic at HR 115.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for underlying source of infection
dynamic_flow.reply: No evidence of biliary obstruction is found. Colonoscopy later reveals diverticulosis but no active diverticulitis.
Abscess fluid grows Klebsiella pneumoniae, sensitive to ceftriaxone and metronidazole.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about follow-up imaging
dynamic_flow.reply: A repeat ultrasound after 2 weeks shows reduction of abscess size from 5 cm to 2 cm.
Antibiotics are continued for a total of 6 weeks, tailored to culture results.
The patient is counseled on completing antibiotics, recognizing recurrence symptoms, and the need for follow-up imaging.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of liver abscess based on clinical presentation and imaging
Initiation of empiric antibiotics and culture-directed therapy
Appropriate use of percutaneous drainage vs. antibiotics alone
Evaluation for underlying source of infection
Monitoring treatment response with follow-up imaging and prolonged antibiotic therapy

rubric.resident_feedback_template: Strengths:You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing liver abscess early and pursuing appropriate imaging. You prioritized empiric antibiotics and drainage appropriately. Communication with the care team was clear and structured. Areas for Improvement:Earlier evaluation for potential sources of infection would have strengthened your approach. Timely escalation when the patient deteriorated could have been more immediate. Review the criteria for when antibiotics alone may suffice versus when drainage is required.
